awd_titl_txt: II-EN: Collaborative Research: Enhancing the Parasol Experimental Testbed for Sustainable Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will enhance an experimental datacenter for sustainable computing. Datacenters consume vast amounts of energy, totaling about 1.8% of the US electricity usage in 2014. Thus, the energy efficiency, energy-related costs, and overall sustainability of datacenters are of critical concerns. NSF funded experimental green datacenter called Parasol has previously demonstrated that the combination of green design and intelligent software management systems can lead to significant reductions in energy consumption, carbon emission, and cost. The enhanced version of this project will update energy sources, network technologies and management software.

Running real experiments in live conditions using Parasol led to findings that were not possible in simulation. This proposal seeks to update and enhance Parasol with current and next generation power-efficient servers, improve network connectivity and integrate software-defined networking (SDN) and Wi-Fi capabilities, increase solar energy generation capacity, add a low emission fuel cell power source, diversify energy storage, and improve the cooling system to advance green computing. The PIs will need to update and enhance Parasol's current software stack for monitoring, programmatic control, and remote access for the new hardware enhancements. Specific research goals are resource management in green datacenters, that includes coordinated workload, cooling, and energy scheduling against environmental and load variability to maximize the benefits of green datacenters and to help improve grid power management leveraging accelerators such as GPUs and deep learning hardware, which promise excellent performance/watt ratios.

por.por_cntn:
The Parasol “green” micro-datacenter was built to provide an isolated and instrumented testbed in support of research on sustainable computing. It has proven to be an extremely effective instrument for research involving power/energy, cooling, and their coordination with and impact on resource management, scheduling, and system/application performance and dependability. As cloud computing evolves rapidly to include “edge” computing, Parasol will also provide an effective platform for studying edge datacenters and their uses to support novel application services.  This project updated and enhanced Parasol to extend its lifetime and increase its capabilities.  Specifically, we populated the enhanced testbed, called Parasol-II, with state-of-the-art heterogeneous servers, hardware accelerators, and improved network connectivity. We also enhanced Parasol-II’s datacenter infrastructure byenhancing its hybrid cooling system and improving the internal separation between the hot and cold isles. Using Parasol-II, researchers at Rutgers, Stony Brook University (SBU), and The Ohio State University (OSU) led research on green computing and energy efficiency, the design of cutting-edge workloads driven by accelerators, and the design of edge computing facilities. Specific research areas included (1) Resource management in green datacenters, including issues such as coordinated workload, cooling, and energy scheduling in the presence of environmental and load variability to maximize the benefits of green datacenters. (2) Scheduling of emerging edge datacenter applications such as object recognition and video processing on heterogeneous hardware, including CPUs, GPUs, and video encoding/decoding accelerators, and in the context of green edge datacenters. (3) Developing analytic models to manage accelerators and processing speeds across whole racks as energy budgets vary—i.e., computational sprinting. (4) Using green edge data and computation centers in distributed application workflows that span mobile, edge, in-transit, and cloud computing. And, (5) an adaptive automatic configuration management framework that can help users and applications adapt to changing runtime conditions for appropriate tradeoff between application quality and resource availability and consumption.  There were several notable outcomes.  At SBU, PIs Gandhi and Liu leveraged Parasol-II’s GPU-equipped servers to evaluate their TensorFlow placement and scheduling work, Pesto. This work was published in ACM/IFIP Middleware 2021. Pesto’s software is publicly available on PI Gandhi’s webpage. PI Liu and his students also studied how to schedule jobs over interchangeable resources, like CPUs and GPUs, to optimize performance while providing fairness among users in a shared cluster such as Parasol-II. The results were published in Eurosys 2021 and the software is publicly available on Github. The interdisciplinary nature of these projects provided valuable theoretical and hands-on learning opportunities to the various graduate students engaged in the project and formed the core of the dissertation for two doctoral students. The project also strengthened collaboration between SBU and Rutgers personnel.  At OSU, PI Stewart leveraged Parasol-II’s GPU-equipped servers to devise neural network approximations for radar waveform design.  This work was published at MPDI Sensors.  In terms of green data centers, PI Stewart led research on computational sprinting for burstable computational resources published at Eurosys 2018. At Rutgers, PI Nguyen and his research group used data from Parasol to create models for designing a deep reinforcement learning agent to manage green datacenters. The group is currently implementing a prototype of the system in Parasol-II to study performance in a real system.
